qas.question: What is distinct from the self?
What can the literature of self-psychology offer insight into?
What have theorists shown interest in relating to the self-concept?
The I and the Me are two areas of interest in what?
What is synonymous with identity question
What offers little insight into how identity is maintained?

plausible_answers.text: the processes by which a self is formed (the "I"), and the actual content of the schemata which compose the self-concept (the "Me").

qas.question: What are the vantage point of group psychology?
Who has shown this self-concept and self-esteem are the same?

context: Although the <b4_0>self<b4_0/> is distinct from <a0_0>identity<a0_0/>, <b5_0>the literature of self-psychology<b5_0/> can offer some insight into <a1_0>how identity is maintained<a1_0/> (Cote & Levin 2002, p. 24). From the vantage point of <a3_0>self-psychology<a3_0/>, there are two areas of interest: <b6_0>the processes by which a self is formed (the "I"), and the actual content of the schemata which compose the self-concept (the "Me").<b6_0/> In the latter field, <b7_0>theorists<b7_0/> have shown interest in relating the self-concept to <a2_0>self-esteem<a2_0/>, the differences between complex and simple ways of organizing self-knowledge, and the links between those organizing principles and the processing of information (Cote & Levin 2002).
